Well, the goal of this project is to raise the level of conversation in this country about what race is and what race isn't.
And we're doing this through museum exhibit, a public website and the development of educational materials for both teachers and families to talk about race.

Why do you say it's cultural?
Well it's cultural because it is not a reality in the natural world.
There's no such thing as humans - humans can not be divided into races because we are one species.
So it's not a biological fact.
But these hierarchies, social hierarchies, have been constructed that are highly racialized.
So that we have an artificial kind of social and cultural construction of what race is and who is raced and who is at the top of the race heap and who's at the bottom of the race heap.
And as a result of that, we also have racism and racist institutions that are embedded in our every-day life.
And so we unlock those as well.
